title-group.article-title: Exploring the middle ground between environmental protection and economic growth

author-notes.corresp: Michael D. Kaplowitz, Department of Community, Agriculture, Recreation, and Resource Studies, 331c Natural Resources, Michigan State University, East Lansing, MI 48824, USA. Email: kaplowit@msu.edu

abstract.p: Public preference concerning the environment and the economy typically has been characterized as either pro-environmental protection or pro-economic development. Researchers and policymakers increasingly suggest that environmental protection and economic growth are not mutually exclusive. However, use of dichotomous-choice policy preference questions persists. This note empirically examines an alternative response format for the typical dichotomous-choice environmental/economic policy preference question and explores respondents’ stated policy preferences in light of their support for recycling. We find that most respondents do not view environmental protection and economic development policy goals to be mutually exclusive. Most respondents view economic growth and environmental protection as compatible suggesting a more heterogeneous view of the environment–economic relationship than oft reported. Hence excluding a middle response choice to the standard environment/economic policy preference question may add measurement error, increase item nonresponse, and fail to account for the views of respondents who view these goals as complementary.

sec.title: 1. Introduction
sec.p: Inquiries into public support for environmental protection typically have framed individuals as pro-environmental protection or pro-economic growth (Dunlap et al., 1993; Neumayer, 2004; Nisbet and Myers, 2007). Survey-based inquiries of public preferences around the globe often use a standard dichotomous-choice environmental/economic policy preference question (see Figure 1) (Dunlap et al., 1993; Gallup, 2010; Schultz et al., 2005; World Values Survey (WVS), 2010). However, forcing respondents to select between either economic growth or environmental protection policy may be ill suited for our times (Goetz et al., 1996; Hand and Macheski, 2003). This article empirically examines the impact of offering a middle (both) response choice to respondents to the standard environment/economy policy preference question.

sec.title: Public opinion inquiry and survey response
sec.p: Researchers generally agree that public opinion influences public policy (Burstein, 2003). World over, surveys help gauge public attitudes and opinions including those about science (Bauer and Schoon, 1993; Lorenzoni and Hulme, 2009). Insights of the public’s environmental values can improve our understanding of the social construction of environmental issues and policies (Major and Atwood, 2004). Surveys can help incorporate public opinion and preferences into environmental policymaking (Gregory, 2000; Lester, 1997). However, cognitive and design challenges may complicate and interfere with surveys accurately measuring attitudes and opinions (Schuman and Scott, 1987; Sudman et al., 1996). Other elicitation methods may be used for garnering public opinions about science and policy (Kleinman et al., 2011; Lorenzoni and Hulme, 2009; Rowe and Frewer, 2000; Walls et al., 2011). However, these approaches have their own set of methodological and theoretical issues and limitations. This article focuses on the continued use of a dichotomous-choice question to gauge public support of environmental protection (economic growth) policies.

Survey questions may measure public opinion but they may also influence outcomes because of the way they frame issues, order alternatives, and otherwise contextualize the question (Schuman and Presser, 1996; Tourangeau et al., 2000; Zaller and Feldman, 1992). As a result, increased efforts have advanced methods for designing, testing, and evaluating survey questions and questionnaires (Presser et al., 2004). Binder et al. (2011) recently tested alternative question designs (single-item versus multi-item) for measuring public opinion regarding perceived risks and benefits of emerging technologies. Likewise, Cacciatore et al. (2011) examined response options order effects on public opinion of technological innovation. The environmental/economic policy preference question may also give rise to concerns regarding order effects of responses or the grouping of two unique attitude objects in a single survey question. The broad goal of our case study is to identify some of the shortcomings that may arise when survey researchers view public opinion as fitting neatly into predefined dichotomous categories instead of as being more nuanced and heterogeneous. In particular, we empirically examine response differences to the standard environmental/economic policy preference question when respondents are given an alternative response set that includes a middle option.

sec.title: “Environment versus economy”
sec.p: Surveys have used a dichotomous-choice environmental/economic policy preference question to classify people as either pro-environmental protection or pro-economic growth in the United States since 1985 (Gallup, 2010), in 24 nations as part of the Health of the World Study (Dunlap et al., 1993), and in more than 80 countries as part of the World Values Survey beginning in 1995 (WVS, 2010). At the same time, researchers use the dichotomous-choice environmental/economic question as an indicator variable of public support for the environment in their models (e.g., Greenberg, 2004; Kempton, 1993) and as a measure of environmental values, attitudes or beliefs in other analyses (Dunlap and Yolk, 2008; Neumayer, 2004; Papadakis, 2000). However, the dichotomous-choice environmental/economic policy preference question may have outlived its usefulness (Cohen, 2009; Stevenson, 2009).

Cohen (1998) describes an ongoing societal reframing of the relationship between economics and the environment; moving from the 1970s’ remedial approaches of environmental policy towards approaches that promise improved economic competitiveness with increased environmental stewardship (i.e., Ecological Modernization) (see also Murphy and Gouldson, 2000). Likewise, individuals’ environmental values reportedly range from a “dominant social paradigm” with greater emphasis on economic growth to a “New Environmental Paradigm” or “Revised New Ecological Paradigm” (Dunlap and Van Liere, 1984; Dunlap et al., 2000) that emphasize the inherent value of nature and wilderness. Increasingly, studies find a substantial majority of respondents preferring outcomes that give equal emphasis to environmental protection and economic development goals (Hand and Macheski, 2003; Papadakis, 2000). It no longer appears axiomatic that being “green” means being inefficient, uncompetitive, or economically costly (Porter, 2008). Likewise, environmental policies are being touted as capable of promoting “win–win” opportunities encouraging both economic benefits and environmental improvement (Pataki, 2009). In an era where economic activity is increasingly coupled with “green” activity, a dichotomous choice between economic growth and environmental protection does seem anachronistic (Goetz et al., 1996; Hand and Macheski, 2003).

sec.title: Dichotomous-choice and middle (intermediate) response choice questions
sec.p: Survey questionnaires often ask respondents to choose between contrasting alternatives—“Does the government provide too much or too little foreign aid?” Dichotomous-choice questions may provide some empirical efficiency, may force uncertain respondents to decide, but they may also miss the mark and induce less reliability and validity (Bishop et al., 1978). Providing respondents with some middle or intermediate response option, in addition to the two “polar” response alternatives, has been considered for such questions (Kalton et al., 1980; Schuman and Presser, 1996). Some suggest that including a middle response option may increase the validity and reliability of the question (Lozano et al., 2008; O’Muircheartaigh et al., 2000; Presser and Schuman, 1980; Saris and Gallhofer, 2007). Others report that offering a middle or no-opinion response option enables researchers to differentiate respondents who actually may be indifferent (Fenichel et al., 2009; Krosnick, 2002; Nowlis et al., 2002). However, there are instances where researchers want to capture “leaners” in a distribution so a middle response category is not included (Kalton et al., 1980). In their 1992 Eurobarometer examination of attitudes about science, Pardo and Calvo (2002) found that fewer respondents to the environmental science items selected “don’t know” when their answer choice sets included an intermediate response option. However, it has been suggested that providing respondents with a middle response option may invite “satisficing” by giving respondents an “easy” response choice that requires little effort and justification (Krosnick, 1991).

The dichotomous response format of the standard environmental/economic policy preference question may present respondents with an unsatisfactory set of response choices. Dunlap and Rik (1991) observed that questions with only environmental protection and economic growth as response options appeared to have higher item nonresponse than other environmental attitude questions. Potential respondents to the dichotomous-choice environmental/economic policy preference question might not answer using one of the two “polar” response options because respondents have contradictory thoughts or feelings on the subject (Groves et al., 2002; Krosnick, 2002). The typical environmental/economic policy preference question may not allow for accurate depiction of respondents’ actual worldview (Leiserowitz et al., 2005). However, the effect of including a middle response option to the standard question on the balance of respondents selecting one of the polar policy preference response alternatives (environmental protection or economic growth) is not clear. Offering a “generic” middle response option may increase the proportion of respondents selecting the middle option (Bishop, 1987; Kalton et al., 1980), leave the balance between supporters of the two extreme response alternatives unaffected (Presser and Schuman, 1980), or otherwise impact responses across respondents.

sec.title: Research questions
sec.p: This article empirically examines the dichotomous-choice environmental/economic policy preference question. Offering a middle response option to some respondents allows for the comparison of the proportion of respondents selecting the “polar” policy preference options—environmental protection and economic growth. We also test whether there is a difference in item nonresponse when respondents have a middle response option. Additionally, we explore whether individuals’ stated policy preferences (and the format used to elicit them) relate to their support for initiatives to protect the environment. Finally, we examine if offering a middle response choice reveals a group of respondents with a preference that balances economic and environmental policy goals or a group that appears to be satisficing.

sec.title: Research setting, sample, and design
sec.p: This study was designed to test a survey question design, not produce general population estimates. Members of the sample populations (students, staff, and faculty) were randomly drawn from university records and invited to participate in a Web-based campus planning survey. All members of the sample populations have email and Internet access, as students, faculty and staff at the university are expected to conduct university business online. Such a special population, while not necessarily representative of the general population, is often used for experimental inquiries. Our use of a Web survey with a probability-based sample avoided pitfalls associated with online Web survey panels (Baker et al., 2010). Potential participants in our study sample were invited to participate in the study up to three times, in the event that they did not respond. After accounting for undeliverable and incorrect addresses, the response rate (RR1) was 24.9% with 3,896 respondents completing the survey (AAPOR, 2009). This response rate is in line with response rates for other Web or Internet surveys (Cook et al., 2000; Sheehan, 2001).

The survey instrument was designed, developed, and implemented following best practices, principles, and guidelines suggested by Dillman (2007), Presser et al. (2004), and Kaplowitz et al. (2004). We used a mixed method approach including key informant interviews and focus group discussions to collect baseline information followed by iterative pretesting and revision of the campus planning survey. Pretesting revealed issues with the standard environment/economy policy preference question that had been included in the survey; pretest participants repeatedly asked for some type of third alternative to more accurately express their policy preferences. That feedback provided the catalyst for designing this study. As a result, alternative “middle” responses were considered. The selection of a “both” response option as the middle option for this study was suggested by pretest participants and supported by further pretesting.

Because of university administration’s desire to have results comparable to previous reported research using the “standard” policy preference question, the Web survey was programmed to randomly assign the “standard” environmental/economic policy preference question with its dichotomous response choices to two-thirds of respondents and to provide the same question with the “alternative” three response choice set to one-third of respondents (i.e., they had an additional “Both” response option for this question). Otherwise, the surveys were identical—all study participants were asked the same substantive and demographic questions in the same order. We account for the uneven sampling proportions in all of our analyses by using proper uneven population statistical procedures.

sec.title: Variables and model
sec.p: To empirically test the research questions, possible responses to the economic/environmental policy preference question were coded as dummy variables (Env(ABC), Env(AB), Both(ABC), Econ(AB), Econ(ABC)) in such a way to account for the question format assigned to potential respondents (standard=AB, alternative=ABC) as well as respondents’ stated policy preference (pro-environment (Env), pro-economy (Econ), or both (Both)). For example, individuals coded as Env(AB) selected environmental protection as their policy preference when asked their policy preference with two response options (treatment AB).

The regression has several dummy variables and some continuous variables including REI, a composite measure of two questions with an acceptable Cronbach alpha of 0.78. Study participants are members of a university community that has a sophisticated and pervasive recycling program. sec.p: The dependent variable, EPI, is a simplified version of Inglehart’s (1995) environmental protection index computed from three inter-correlated survey items to measure respondents’ support for environmental undertakings. Such truncated versions of environmental attitudinal scales have been effective in previous studies (e.g., Bord et al., 2000). Heath and Gifford (2006) suggest that perceived self-efficacy (PSE), an individual’s belief that the things one does make a difference, is a prerequisite for personal action. Hence, individuals with strong beliefs (PSE) in their ability to effect positive environmental change (on campus through recycling) should be more willing than others to support pro-environmental initiatives. Individuals’ environmental knowledge has also been suggested as a motivator of pro-environmental intent and behavior (e.g., Cheung et al., 1999; Do Valle et al., 2004). Accordingly, level of respondents’ knowledge of the environmental benefits (of their recycling actions) (KEB) and their receptivity to (recycling) information (REI) should be positively related to their EPI.

Pelletier et al. (1996) reported that individuals with higher levels of satisfaction with environmental conditions (SCI) were associated with lower frequencies of financial support to pro-environmental groups, voting for pro-environmental political parties, and involvement with environmental groups. We expected the EPI of respondents in our study to move in the opposite direction as their level of satisfaction with campus recycling (SCI). Model (1) also includes variables for respondents’ age and income since these characteristics are typically included as important explanatory variables (Van Liere and Dunlap, 1980).

sec.title: 4. Results
sec.p: The descriptive statistics of our respondents coincide with the demographic characteristics of the three population segments. Faculty members (50.24 yrs) on average are older than staff members (46.04 yrs) who are in turn older than the average student age (23.43 yrs). To examine the income of the constituent groups, we used the midpoint of income ranges reported by each respondent. Not surprisingly, faculty have a much higher mean income (~$98,000) than staff (~$55,000); students (~$8000) are the lowest income group. To examine possible sample bias, we compared characteristics of our respondents with those demographics reported by the university. The average student age in our sample is almost identical with the student population average age of 23.35 years. Our student sample contained 43.1% males; at the time, the university reported the population to be 45.9% male. Furthermore, we compared demographic characteristics from our sample with data from other surveys of the same population and found similar sample characteristics. Because of limitations on disclosure of personal information of students and employees by the university we do not have complete demographic and other characteristics of all the strata nor any demographic information on individual non-respondents.

sec.title: Effect of middle alternative on response distribution
sec.p: The effect on response distributions of offering a middle option to the environmental/economic policy preference question is illustrated in Figure 2. The presence of the middle option did change the distribution of responses in the polar extremes. Almost three-quarters (73.5%) of respondents presented with the dichotomous response options (AB) indicated a policy preference for environmental protection. In contrast, 62% of respondents to the response treatment including a “Both” option (ABC) indicated a policy preference for the both policies alternative (C), with 30% of respondents selecting environmental protection (A) as their preferred policy goal.

caption.p: Response distribution by response choice treatment—AB or ABC.

sec.p: This finding is in line with previous research suggesting that offering a middle option results in a large number of respondents selecting such an alternative. At the same time, these results support the notion that most respondents do not perceive the two policy goals, environmental protection and economic growth, as mutually exclusive, and chose the middle option because it reflects their “true” preference.

It turns out that respondents selecting the middle option were not proportionately drawn from both polar extremes. The split between environment (A) and economy (B) responses in treatment AB was 73.5% (A) and 26.5% (B) while in treatment ABC it was 79% (A) and 21% (B) when responses to the middle option are excluded. This difference in the proportion of respondents selecting A or B in the two treatments is statistically significant (χ2(1, 2883) = 6.26, p < 0.001). Respondents preferring policies promoting both environmental protection and economic growth were disproportionately drawn from the pool of individuals likely to have indicated a pro-economic policy preference in the dichotomous-choice format. Whether or not this pro-environmental tendency is a reflection of only our sample population’s preferences, these results illustrate that offering a middle response option with the environmental/economic policy question does not necessarily pull responses equally from the policy preference poles.

sec.title: Effect of middle alternative on nonresponse
sec.p: Overall, about 5% of study participants in both treatment groups started but did not complete the survey; they are excluded from the item nonresponse rate calculations and analyses. Table 2 shows that item nonresponse for treatment AB (2.3%) is statistically greater than item nonresponse for treatment ABC (0.6%) (χ2(1, 3716) = 14.0, p < 0.001).1 Interestingly, the 0.6% nonresponse rate for treatment ABC’s policy preference question is the same as the average item nonresponse rate for all other survey items in the study. While the AB treatment’s nonresponse rate may not be large enough by itself to be a major cause of concern in most surveys, the significant difference in item nonresponse for the two response treatments suggests that the standard questions and dichotomous response choices do result in potential respondents skipping the item. These results suggest that there is value in exploring alternative question/response formats to the dichotomous-choice environmental/economic policy preference question.

sec.title: Environment/economic policy preferences and EPI
sec.p: Table 3 presents the results of the regression analysis of model (1). The results indicate that the environmental/economic policy preference of participants is predictive of their level of support for environmental protection initiatives (EPI). The model accounts for about 25.1% of the variance in EPI (F(10, 3545) = 119.44, p < 0.001). About half of this explained variance (13%) is attributed to respondents’ environmental/economic policy preference. This underscores the important role of individuals’ environmental/economic policy preferences vis-à-vis their pro-environmental undertakings.

sec.p: Model (1) allows for comparing the effect of each policy preference group on EPI relative to a baseline policy preference, in our case Both(ABC). The results demonstrate that respondents indicating a pro-environmental policy preference (Env(AB) and Env(ABC)) had significantly higher levels of EPI than respondents in the Both(ABC) group. At the same time, respondents indicating a pro-economic policy preference (Econ(AB) and Econ(ABC)) had significantly lower levels of EPI than the Both(ABC) group. Analyses across response treatment groups (treatment AB v. treatment ABC) reveal that pro-environmental policy respondents in treatment AB differed significantly in their level of support of environmental initiatives from pro-environmental policy respondents in treatment ABC at the 5% significance level. Likewise, significant differences are observed concerning pro-economic policy respondents. The significant effect of policy preference on EPI, in descending order of magnitude, is Environment (ABC) > Environment (AB) > Both (ABC) > Economic (AB) > Economic (ABC).

Table 3 also shows that respondents’ other personal characteristics, PSE, KEB, REI, and SCI, influence their stated level of support of environmental initiatives as theorized. That is, respondents with higher levels of PSE, KEB, and REI were associated with higher EPI scores while those who reported greater satisfaction with the current recycling initiative (SCI) were associated with lower EPI scores. While the age of respondents was not significant in our model, income was a significant explanatory variable for increased support for environmental initiatives. For the purposes of this article, suffice to say that the model revealed that use of a middle response option to the environmental/economic preference question revealed groups of respondents that differ significantly in their preferences and personal characteristics from those in the polar policy response groups.

sec.title: Middle alternative and satisficing
sec.p: The foregoing reveals an ordered ranking of policy preferences with “Both” in the middle. However, are respondents selecting the “Both” option because they are satisficing rather than revealing their true preference? When the middle response option (both) was available, a majority of respondents selected it. Yet, as we observed, those selecting the middle response option were not drawn equally from the two ends of the policy spectrum. Respondents indicating a policy preference for environmental protection (economic growth) when given an option of a “Both” alternative had significantly higher (lower) EPI than respondents selecting environmental protection (economic growth) when given only two response alternatives. Moreover, the EPI for respondents selecting the middle option of “Both” was significantly different from all other treatments (p < .0001). To examine if respondents selecting a policy preference of “Both” might simply have selected middle response options as a response strategy to avoid making thoughtful selections (also known as “straight lining”), we compared the frequency of respondents selecting the “Both” option for the policy preference question to that of respondents selecting middle options in other survey questions. We found that, on average, only 27% of respondents selecting the “Both” option for the environmental/economic policy question also selected at least one middle option in other survey questions. Therefore, satisficing, if present in our study, would be a result of respondents’ motivations or the difficulty of the task. It seems that respondents selecting the middle option to our environmental/economic policy question do so because they value both or some combination of the two policy alternatives.

sec.title: 5. Discussion and conclusion
sec.p: Assessments of public understanding of science typically rely on the a priori definitions researchers make regarding what questions to ask and how to ask them. Inaccurate or overly narrow predefinitions of the range of public opinion during the design of surveys could thus introduce some measurement errors and potentially lead researchers to inaccurately assess the public view. In the research reported here, we employed the oft-used environmental/economic preference question which allows for the standard dichotomous response options. Our case study identifies some of the shortcomings that may arise when survey researchers view public opinion as fitting neatly into predefined dichotomous categories instead of as being more nuanced and heterogeneous.

While acknowledging the potential value of using a dichotomous format to force respondents to choose among alternative goals, we find that there is value in modifying the standard environment versus economy policy preference question to reflect the sometimes complementary relationship of the policy goals. Our results indicate that many respondents do not think of environmental policy and economic growth as goals that are always mutually exclusive and that a dichotomous response array does not conform with the preferences of a significant portion of potential respondents. Providing respondents to the environment/economic policy question with a “both” response alternative is one way to better account for the range of public preferences regarding environmental and economic policy goals. Not providing some middle response option with the standard environmental/economic policy preference question, it seems, forces (the majority of) respondents to choose one of the “extreme” response options. Doing so may add measurement error, increase item nonresponse, and fail to adequately account for respondents who believe that both of these policies should be pursued or that these two policy goals are not mutually exclusive.

Interestingly, the recent American National Election Study (ANES, 2010) explored similar public policy preferences using an alternative approach—rating two statements as opposite ends of a seven-point response scale:

list-item.p: “Some people feel that the government in Washington should protect the environment even if it costs jobs and reduces the standard of living”
“Other people feel that maintaining jobs and a good standard of living is more important than protecting the environment”

sec.p: The ANES use of an answer scale, rather than a dichotomous question, appears to better allow for respondents who may not believe that there is/must be an all or nothing trade-off between the environment and the economy.

These results, along with our findings, suggest measurement error and item nonresponse bias issues for other uses of such double-barreled questions, like the one in WVS, to distinguish preferences. As Fiske and Tetlock (1997) point out, as subjects are forced to make trade-offs which generate value conflicts for the respondents (e.g., economic growth or environmental protection), they may respond in ways not anticipated by investigators. There is an assortment of alternative approaches for measuring subjects’ preferences that includes: interval rating scales; forced rankings; multiple-response, multiple-choice questions; regression analysis; and conjoint analysis. Although each of these alternative approaches has its own set of methodological and theoretical shortcomings and/or limitations, our results combined with the evidence in the literature suggest that these alternative approaches deserve consideration and further investigation.

Our results also highlight the relative importance of respondents’ other characteristics, attitudes, and beliefs as predictors of their support for pro-environmental efforts. Individuals’ economic/environment policy preferences do seem predictive of their support for environmental initiatives. Improved measures of respondents’ policy preferences as they relate to prioritizing economic growth and/or environmental protection may lead to better designed efforts for advancing important policy agendas such as sustainable economic development and business-friendly environmental protection. While the results suggest that a middle response option may be helpful, it remains to be tested whether more or different “middle” response options or whether new question formats would provide greater reliability and insight. Likewise, it remains unresolved whether the benefits of a new question/response format would outweigh the benefits of backward comparability with prior formats of the environmental/economic policy preference questions. Obviously, there is room for further inquiry.

bio.title: Author biographies
bio.p: Michael D. Kaplowitz is a professor of Environmental Law and Policy in the Department of Community, Agriculture, Recreation, and Resource Studies at Michigan State University. His research interests include the study of research methods, natural resource and watershed management, ecosystem services, and nonmarket valuation.

Frank Lupi is a professor of Natural Resource and Environmental Economics at Michigan State University. His expertise includes the econometrics and development of stated-choice surveys and recreation demand analyses.

Felix K. Yeboah is a doctoral student in the Department of Community, Agriculture, Recreation, and Resource Studies at Michigan State University. His research interests include the human dimensions of environmental change, pro-poor growth strategies, and program evaluation.

Laurie G. Thorp is the director of the Residential Initiative on the Study of the Environment, an interdisciplinary living/learning option at Michigan State University. Her research interests are focused on participatory methodologies for food systems change.
